H0.text: A material that has high porosity and high permeability is the most effective aquifer because it contains more empty space and its pores are well connected, allowing water to move freely.

H1.text: A material that has high porosity and low permeability would make the most effective aquifer, because it contains many empty spaces (pores) yet the pores are poorly connected, limiting water movement.

H2.text: A material that has low porosity and high permeability would make the most effective aquifer.

H3.text: A material that has low porosity and low permeability is the material that would make the most effective aquifer, based on the definitions that empty spaces in a material are called pores, porosity is the amount of empty space within a material, and permeability describes how well the pores in a material are connected.

A6.text: Porosity can be proportional to hydraulic conductivity; for two similar sandy aquifers, the one with a higher porosity will typically have a higher hydraulic conductivity (more open area for the flow of water), but there are many complications to this relationship.

A7.text: porosity is the amount of empty space within a material, and permeability describes how well the pores in a material are connected

A8.text: Graphical depiction of different flow rates through materials of differing permeability
